It's not all that hard to understand, actually.
 
 Generally, things work out as intended. People pay for what they buy, people are left alone and so on. Law is obeyed, but it is never actually activated. Law thus only gets into focus when things go wrong.
 
 However, this means that people only get into contact with the law "at a bad time". Law and lawyers may not create problems, but are just called into action when problems arise, but this does not prevent the general public from associating the law and the lawyer with everything bad that happens in these circumstances.
 
 A side issue is that law is generally impartial, which means it is never actually completely on "your" side, and with common "either with me or against me" psychology, this results in the law being accused of taking "their" side.
 
 Of course, the fact that being a lawyer demands some serious education and that services of hghly educated people are generally quite expensive. Especially since everyone feels that justice should be free, especially to the one that is right, i.e. the one who is making the opinion.
 
 Next, we get to what that means in practice. Look at my post in the topic below for an explanation of why things are done as they are.
